Award.AwardTitle: International Institute for Multifunctional Materials for Energy Conversion (IIMEC)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award establishes an International Materials Institute for Multifunctional Materials for Energy Conversion (IIMEC) at the Texas Engineering Experiment Station in partnership with Georgia Institute of Technology, the University of Houston and international collaborations at universities in North Africa (Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt), the Middle East (Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Kuwait) and Mediterranean countries (Turkey, Cyprus, Greece, France). The international collaborations of IIMEC builds on connections facilitated by a Texas A&M branch campus in Qatar opened in 2003, a newly established Institute for Applied Mathematics and Computational Science in Saudi Arabia funded by King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, The Georgia Tech campus in Lorraine, France and an exchange program between University of Houston and Tunisia. The research thrust is on computational modeling and experiments to study the cross-coupling of multiple functionalities, for example, thermal,/magnetic and mechanical coupling in shape memory alloys and polymers; coupling of electrical and mechanical properties in electroactive polymers, ceramics and composite materials; thermal/optical and electrical coupling for photovolatics, thermoelectrics, and fuel cell applications. IIMEC would establish a high performance computational infrastructure and high speed communications protocols to facilitate research and educational collaboration on multifunctional materials among its partners while expanding the global network. The Institute offers opportunities for undergraduate, graduate students as well as junior and established scientists to engage in international research, exchange visits among partners, seed programs to promote new collaborations and members, and instrumentation development for remote use among partnering international institutions. The Institute's management leadership is provided by its Directors and an Executive Committee, with guidance from an Advisory Board and an International Leadership Team.
This award is jointly funded by the Division of Materials Research in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate and the Africa, Near East & South Asia group of the Office of the International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Institute for Multifunctional Materials for Energy Conversion (IIMEC) succeeded to enhance the contribution and interaction of Middle Eastern, Mediterranean, and North African participating institutions among themselves and with the US institutions–Texas A&M University, Georgia Tech, University of Houston, and Pennsylvania State University–in addressing scientific problems related to energy conversion among different fields and establishing strong educational ties to train next generation work force in multifunctional materials.

IIMEC started its activities having interactions with 8 countries - Qatar, Saudi Arabia, France, Greece, Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt, and Turkey. Throughout the years this number increased to 14, with Cyprus, Spain, Italy, Oman, Algeria, and Germany becoming part of the IIMEC circle of collaborators. IIMEC sent over 50 US students abroad to participate in exchange programs, summer schools and workshops and about 60 students from participating countries came to US institutions for exchange programs. Also the faculty exchange opportunity initiated by the IIMEC resulted in over 40 faculty exchanges between university participants.

IIMEC established further mechanisms to enhance materials education at the international level by organizing intensive summer/winter schools, short courses, invited talks and lectures at the various participating sites to disseminate the knowledge on the research topics associated with the program. Especially the two-week summer school established at Texas A&M University on multiscale methods for multifunctional materials has become a destination for international scholars and pioneered a new framework of teaching computational materials, now adopted in the materials science and engineering curriculum at Texas A&M University and it has been considered for implementation by several other universities in the US and abroad. A focused summer school on multifunctional composites has also been established as an annual event in Europe and with a commitment from the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki to continue it beyond the IIMEC support. Additional successful workshops and annual meetings have taken place in Turkey, Morocco, Egypt, Qatar and France.

IIMEC’s research efforts resulted in more than 280 joint publications in peer-reviewed journals, book chapters, and several patents in three specific research areas: i) conversion of thermal/magnetic into mechanical energy induced by a reversible phase transformation; ii) conversion via material properties coupling of electrical into mechanical energy; and iii) thermal and electrical, and optical and electrical combined functionalities via material properties coupling. From all students who were involved with the IIMEC, 24 graduated from their Masters, PhD or Post Doctorate programs.

IIMEC established a computational cluster for computational materials software to be used by all participants in a collaborative environment and internet communications with international participants. The cluster is well suited for high performance computation and has been integrated into a shared queue in the supercomputing facility at Texas A&M University. The IIMEC website (http://iimec.tamu.edu) is designed to include links to other IMIs, archives of IIMEC’s activities with downloadable documentation such as presentations and photos of events, a forum where any member can initiate a discussion, share information and engage other members.
